text: (bright music begins)
I'm very excited to give this talk
to such a broad audience of speakers
and people who have zoomed into this symposium.
I wanted to start by thanking Chemical and Engineering News
for organizing this symposium,
and I'm very honored to have been selected
as part of the class of 2021.
So with that,
I wanted to focus this presentation on
sharing some of the boarder interest in my lab
where we try to address some different questions
in immunology and neuroinflammation
by the application of chemical proteomic approaches.
But before I go into more science,
I wanted to start by also describing
my journey to the Rockefeller University.
So I was born and raised in Moscow, Russia,
where my parents did a fantastic job
raising me and my sister by taking us out
to dacha every summer where we could go
and grow vegetables and go mushroom picking.
But by also focusing on making sure
that we learned English very early on,
which is a very useful skill as I've learned over the years,
as well as my mom played a big role by being very proactive
with seeking out opportunities for both me and my sister
in terms of our education.
And she was the reason why I attended a high school
that was focusing on chemistry, actually very early on,
and started doing research very early on
in like conjugate chemistry and polysaccharide analytics.
After high school, I went on to do my MSc studies
in higher chemical college of Russian Academy of Sciences,
but there were a number of people who have influenced
and shaped my scientific interests during that time,
as I've gone on a number of internships around the world,
including United States, Switzerland, and France.
And I'm very grateful for all the mentors that I've met
throughout these experiences,
both working on my master thesis with Yulia
but also going to do research internships around the globe.
And if you pay more attention to the list of the names,
you will recognize a theme emerging.
I was very attracted to organometallic chemistry
back in the days,
and it was not a surprise for my family
when I decided to go to MIT to pursue my PhD studies,
or with Steve Buchwald,
doing research in organometallic chemistry,
and mostly working on applying
organometallic chemistry approaches
to expand our synthetic toolbox,
but also in the very end of my PhD studies,
applying organometallic chemistry
to chemical biology and bioconjugation in collaboration,
with Brad Pentelute's lab.
Following my PhD studies,
I moved across the country
to pursue my post-doctoral work with Ben Cravatt,
where I really took a deeper dive
into chemical biology and chemical proteomics,
and worked in collaboration with
a number of very talented people,
but in particular,
John Teijaro, who we collaborated on our project
on studying T cells and applying
chemical proteomics platforms to understand
T cell misregulation.
So, as Beth mentioned,
I'm currently an assistant professor
and head of the lab of chemical immunology and proteomics
at Rockefeller University,
and our lab was very recently established in December, 2020.
So our overarching goal in the lab is expanding
our understanding of misregulation of protein function
in disease,
and coming up with new methods
for targeting protein function in disease.
And we tried to do it
in the context of trying to study
the state-dependent chemical immunology and neuroimmunology,
and we do this through the development
of new chemical tools,
which will help us
to block the protein function
through targeting active sites
of proteins or protein degradation,
as well as through the advancement of proteomic platforms.
And I will tell you a little bit more throughout
the talk about this.
So why are we interested in studying
misregulated immune responses?
I guess it won't be an understatement
that the past two years have really highlighted
the role of our immune system
as a guardian against pathogens,
as well as cancer.
But when misregulated immune system
plays a number of deleterious roles,
including playing a causal role
for a number of different diseases,
ranging from auto immune diseases
to neurodegeneration and cancer,
and it is greatly appreciated that immune cells
can undergo a number of phenotypic changes,
which makes them big players in both
human physiology and pathology.
And over the years,
a number of global scale genomic and transcriptomic
approaches have emerged to try to understand these changes
on a more molecular level,
and oftentimes generating unique signatures
for misregulated self states
in specific pathologic conditions,
which lead to identification of a number
of not just misregulated genes,
but also proteins that change in expression
under different pathologic states.
However,
it is very important to know that molecular events
that lead to functional changes
often don't involve changes in gene or protein abundance,
and therefore methods for gaining a better molecular level
understanding of these post-translational changes
are very important.
So, as I already mentioned,
immune cells undergo a number of phenotypic changes.
And a lot of times the phenotypic changes
are associated with biochemical changes,
and these have been studied extensively over the years,
and a number of these changes don't really also go in hand
with the gene expression changes
and require additional methods for studying them.
And furthermore,
how these biochemical changes correspond
to molecular level changes,
as I already mentioned,
is poorly understood,
and our lab wants to develop platforms
to be able to assess these molecular level changes,
to gain new insights into biology,
but also to identify new targets
that can be specifically targeted in itself.
So basically the question that we are asking in the lab
and that I started asking when I was a postdoc
in Ben Cravatt's group,
is can we use these nucleophilic amino acid residues,
such as cysteine and lysine,
as sensors of these biochemical changes
during immune cell misregulation or activation, or both.
And indeed, cysteine has been used as a handle
for protein structure determination,
back in the 1960s,
where Kendrew and Perutz used organomercury complexes
to facilitate x-ray structure determination,
for which they got their Nobel prize for.
Furthermore, cysteine and lysine were used
as handles to study protein dynamics
also back 10 to 20 years ago,
by a number of very accomplished scientists,
three of the Nobel laureates are listed below,
who have contributed to the studies
of using cysteine and lysine as handles
to study protein dynamics to NMR methodologies.
However, these approaches,
while very powerful to study
protein structures and protein dynamics,
only focus on specific proteins in isolated settings.
So what we are trying to ask
and what we're trying to achieve is
we're trying to apply these broad scale proteomic platforms
to gain very similar structural and functional insights
into the biochemistry of proteins
that is changing depending on the cell states.
And there are a number of chemical proteomic platforms
that have been developed over the past,
through the pioneering work of
Ben Carvatt and D'Ambrosio as well.
And the more recent work coming out of their labs
and other labs within the proteomic community.
But these days,
we are able to ask these broad scale questions
where we're looking into, for example,
drug ability on a protium wide-scale
so which sites can across the proteome
can accommodate ligands for drug development purposes,
but also what we call reactivity profiling,
where we are looking at the differences
in the innate reactivity of specific cysteine residues
in different cell states,
and we're trying to use them as a potential opportunity
to target pathological but not physiological states.
And just a little bit in more detail,
when we're using the reactivity profiling platforms,
we're looking at the reactivity of specific sites
and proteins in cells and different states.
And we're looking at the differential relativity
with the broadly reactive iota sediment probes,
or either probes for lysine targeting.
And we're hoping to use this as an unbiased tool
for discovery of biochemical changes in cells.
And indeed, we were able to highlight this
in the case of T-cell activation,
where a number of proteins showed
increased reactivity of specific cysteines
involved in redox regulation,
likely reflecting on a higher reducing potential
of activated T cells.
And I just wanted to also show this example
where we're finding sites that are changing in reactivity
that are close to cofactor or metabolite binding sites,
serving as kind of handouts to read out
the biochemical changes within the cells.
So as I already mentioned,
another approach that we're using is this so-called
druggability or ligandability profiling approach,
which allows us,
through the use of so-called small molecule scout fragments,
to interrogate the whole protium
on the ability of specific residues
to accommodate the cysteine electrophiles
for future drug development purposes.
And indeed the carbene electrophiles possess
a number of benefits for drug development purposes.
And this approach allows us to read out
the thousands of sites in a single proteomic experiment.
And we applied this approach to studying T cell activation
and identified over 3000 sites that can, in theory,
be targeted with small molecule covalent electrophiles,
including sites on the proteins,
which are typically considered harder to drug proteins,
such as adaptor proteins and transcription factors.
And I'm also showing you one target
that highlights the importance of applying these methods
to different cells and different cell states,
because we also identified a number of sites
that can be targeted with
small molecule covalent electrophiles
in checkpoint receptors,
which were only quantified in the activated T cells
versus the quiescent G cells.
So what do we do to advance these ligands
to more elaborated probes?
We usually try to come up with function first approach
as to be able to screen more advanced libraries
of compounds with covalent electrophilic warheads.
And one of the approaches is shown here
where we use the assay for inhibitors of T cell activation.
And we realized that this approach allows us
to identify ligands with unique pharmacology,
where three out of the four compounds
that we were following up on
showed their mechanism of action to involve degradation
of their respective targets from different protein classes.
And most interestingly,
the degradation of the proteins
was actually a state-dependent,
then a very good example of it is this ITK degrader
that I'll briefly go in this story.
So we're interested in this series
of stereoisomeric probes
that we started studying them in collaboration
with professor Schreiber's lab.
And the reason why we are interested in it is
because having sets of these stereoisomeric probes
allows us to streamline the mechanism of action studies,
as well as target focus studies for understanding the roles
of specific targets as they provide both
in structured activity relationship
within the library design.
So indeed we found a set of four compounds
where only one compound,
only one stereoisomer showed inhibition of T cell activation
and looking at the targets of the compounds,
we were able to identify a limited set of targets
that were specific for the active compound,
but I wanted to just highlight that we also believe
that being able to do chemical proteomic profiling
on these stereoisomers also allows us to pick up
compounds that specifically target
their protein targets
in a stereoselective manner,
which allows us to start in additional programs
into looking into the function of those proteins
and the inhibition of those sites.
So going back to the targets of the active compounds,
we also identified ITK and other immune relevant kinase
to be another target of these compounds.
But in this case,
we didn't see this site to be engaged of ITK
because we don't see this peptide
in our proteomics experiments,
but we saw state dependent degradation of ITK
in our whole protium and enrich proteomics experiments.
And here I'm just showing you
the stereoselective degradation of ITK.
And what's very interesting to us
is that the more studies we do,
and the more compounds that we uncover
to be small molecule degraders of protein targets,
is the more we understand
that the ligand does matter for protein degradation.
So by comparing our compound
to the known inhibitor of cysteine 422 and ITK kinase,
we're able to see that while the known inhibitor
actually stabilizes the inactive confirmation of ITK,
our inhibitor leads to ITK degradation,
although the known inhibitor does prevent our compound
from T cell activation induced degradation.
So finding these examples
from our T cell focus study
has really highlighted the fact that
the small molecule covalent electrophiles
can serve as privileged scaffolds for protein degradation.
And we are focusing on building out additional screens
to identify new scaffolds
that can degrade the protein targets
through molecular glue degrader mechanism,
but also through other mechanisms.
And as are the labs,
we're also trying to expand this approach
to building out the PROTACs
which would basically transform our ligands
that we're discovering for specific targets
into potential drug leads
with a functional output through protein degradation.
With that I just wanted to thank Ben
for being an amazing mentor over the years,
and for assembling a fantastic group of people in his lab
who have been helpful throughout my time in Ben's lab.
And I also wanted to thank my new group
at Rockefeller University,
who have been excited about the projects in the lab
and who are very enthusiastic about the science that we do.
I also wanted to thank the funding agencies
and also in particular Rockefeller University,
whose community has been very supportive
while I was starting during the COVID times in 2020.
And just to give
faces to names,
I just wanted to show our current group members in the lab
and just give a small pitch
that we do have positions open for postdoctoral fellows
with cell biology and molecular neuroscience experience
right now in the lab,
so feel free to apply to me directly.
And with that,
I just wanted to thank you for your attention,
and I'm happy to answer any questions.
Thank you so much, Katya.
I'm going to ask one quick question from Dong-Sik Park
who points out there's a lot of files in the cell
and asks basically,
how do you avoid other file containing groups
to get site specificity?
So I think there are a number of good examples
for the development of advanced drugs
that are specific for their respective targets,
including, you know, ibrutinib and acalabrutinib,
so it is a combination of affinity and reactivity
for the cysteine sites.
And another good example is, you know, dimethyl fumarate
which is an approved drug as well
which targets specific cysteines in proteins.
Thanks so much.
(bright music fades out)
